titles.darkblue: Improve reliability and quality of data
titles.purple: Use data to gain insight into users
titles.pink: Use data to improve operational processes
titles.yellow: Use experimentation to inform decision making
titles.line: Embed UX design and research practices
titles.skyblue: Understand user needs to increase engagement

start.copy:
Multi-variant testing

Challenges
Organisations do not know whether their models are adding value or which ones they should use. How can they move from gut instinct or HIPPO opinions?

Typical scenarios are:

  • My teams are building lots of models. How do I know if they are making a difference to my business goals?
  • My data science team has built a number of models for the same purpose. Which model should I use?

Recommendation:
Use multi-variant testing to run multiple models at the same time and evaluate how they affect your business metrics.

AB testing combines the common-sense approach of trying out different variations at the same time, with statistical analysis to run experiments and measure the effect on business outcomes. There are powerful tools to support this which help set up the experiments as well as collecting the measurements. In many cases it is possible to run multiple models at the same time, and to move your business operations to the 'winning' model during the experiment - gaining business benefit whilst the experiment is still in flight.

Often the end result (increase revenue, reduction in fraud etc.) is too difficult/takes too long to evaluate to be of use experimentally. So identify an intermediate metric which is correlated with the required end result.

Resources
???

Examples
John Lewis Recommendations, John Lewis Search, Plusgrade

Services catalogue

Challenges
As organisations scale they struggle to understand which teams are accountable for which services, so resolving any type of delivery challenge at scale becomes extremely difficult and time consuming.

Typical scenarios are:

  • How many teams you have, and how many services you have
  • Which teams own which services
  • Which teams have the most frequent deployments
  • Which teams have had the most recent production incidents
  • How long does it take to put a new service into production

You have multiple, distinct spreadsheets for this data, from your PMO, your architects, and your delivery teams. The spreadsheets are maintained part-time, and constantly inaccurate.

Recommendation:
Use multi-variant testing to run multiple models at the same time and evaluate how they affect your business metrics.

AB testing combines the common-sense approach of trying out different variations at the same time, with statistical analysis to run experiments and measure the effect on business outcomes. There are powerful tools to support this which help set up the experiments as well as collecting the measurements. In many cases it is possible to run multiple models at the same time, and to move your business operations to the 'winning' model during the experiment - gaining business benefit whilst the experiment is still in flight.

Often the end result (increase revenue, reduction in fraud etc.) is too difficult/takes too long to evaluate to be of use experimentally. So identify an intermediate metric which is correlated with the required end result.

You build it, you run it

Agile as a toolkit

Challenges
You want to accelerate the delivery of value-adding features to your customers. You're spending lots of time and money on establishing a centralised delivery process. You might see:

Team members taking spending a lot of time Scrum certification and/or SAFe training Teams are forced to adhere to a particular methodology, even if it slows them down. We've heard people say before 'don't take on any more work, we have to close off the story points for this week' Teams burning a lot of time in meetings, planning for Scrum sprints and/or SAFe program increments

You don't see any reduction in the lead time to customer value. You don't know if all this investment is going to translate into better delivery. Recommendation Use agile as a toolkit within your organisation. Use the best tools from different methodologies. Apply them to your unique situation, to deliver more efficiently and in-line with your teams' preferred ways of working.

We see organisations say “we do Scrum here”, or “we do SAFe here”. Avoid dogmatic over investment in these methodologies, as it restricts the natural evolution of team ways of working. Focus on creating feedback loops, where teams reflect on their current ways of working, and then make incremental changes to improve their ways of working in future iterations. It's an experimental process. Some changes will succeed, others will not. Over time, these improvements will help teams to adapt their ways of working to more efficient delivery.
